description: From Middle English maynouren, manuren (“to supervise, toil”), borrowed from Anglo-Norman meinourer and Old French manovrer (whence also English maneuver), from Vulgar Latin *manuoperare (“work by hand”), from Latin manū (“by hand”) + operārī (“to work”).

entries.meaning: Animal excrement, especially that of common domestic farm animals and when used as fertilizer. Generally speaking, from cows, horses, sheep, pigs and chickens.
Any fertilizing substance, whether of animal origin or not; fertiliser.
examples: Malt dust consists chiefly of the infant radicle separated from the grain. I have never made any experiment upon this manure; but there is great reason to suppose it must contain saccharine matter; and this will account for its powerful effects.
“You know the police think I killed Marge, don't you?”“What a load of manure! I couldn't believe it when I read the paper.”

verbs.description: manure (third-person singular simple present manures, present participle manuring, simple past and past participle manured)

entries.meaning: To cultivate by manual labor; to till; hence, to develop by culture.
examples: Manure thyself then; to thyself be approved; / And with vain, outward things be no more moved.

entries.meaning: To apply manure (as fertilizer or soil improver).
examples: The farmer manured his fallow field.
